column2: ["'Strengthening Resilience of the population living in the Arid Lands of Kenya"]
column5: ['This phase of the ECHO La Nina project will be implemented in Wajir Oxfam GB in partnership with two LNGO partners namely; ALDEF and WASDA who will directly implement activities with the target communities in the County.  These partners have experience in resilience programming, Emergency Preparedness and Response, particular within the Wajir context. This phase builds on 4 previous phases of DG ECHO investment and aims at strengthening the resilience of people in the ASALs, especially women and children, and county structures to better cope and respond to climate shocks and stress.    The Programme will consolidate outputs and outcomes realized through the most recent ECHO -funded project which ended in March 2015. The action is in line with the wider consortium five -year resilience strategy through the improvement and integration of community and county early warning systems that can trigger emergency responses. The action will also continue to strengthen the Community Disaster Management Committees (CDMCs) and particularly build linkages between the CDMCs and relevant stakeholder including County structures to implement their Community Disaster Management Plans (CDMPs). Finally, the action will strengthen the voices of the communities with ground -based advocacy and campaigns.    The action aims at achieving the following three results  1. Strengthened structures/systems for timely, reliable and relevant Early warning information to effectively trigger Early Action within the County  2. Strengthened stakeholder linkages at different levels to support communities/County to plan, prepare and respond to shocks and stresses.  3. Wajir partner (including Oxfam) with capacity to influence emergency and resilience agenda at county level    The action will be implemented in Wajir County as part of wider ASALs (Turkana, Mandera, Wajir, Marsabit, Samburu, Baringo, West Pokot), a region that has suffered from recurrent droughts and extreme climatic conditions with devastating']

column2: ['Turkana drought response']
column5: ["Oxfam is targeting the most vulnerable people in Turkana, where it has been working since the 1960's and has an established presence and long term partnerships to build on. Specifically, Oxfam will target women and children that don't have access to water and food or have to walk large distances to reach water sources, as well as vulnerable population groups like lactating women, elderly and children that are at risk of dropping out of the school system.  To identify beneficiaries, communities and locations to target Oxfam will partner closely with the Turkana county (local government), with the Water User Associations (WUAs) and the Water Users Committees (WUCs), , and with the Hunger Safety Net Programme 2, to utilise the experience of these authorities when it comes to needs and targeting. Oxfam will also work in schools, health centres and in the communities to identify the most vulnerable House Holds (HHs). Beneficiary selection will be undertaken in a participatory manner ensuring participation of the most vulnerable groups such as women headed households, households with pregnant and lactating women, elders and with children below 5 years. There will be selected community members acting as beneficiary reference groups who can share the feelings and feedback of the community towards the project to ensure accountability. This process of community -based targeting has the benefit of bringing local knowledge and priorities into the programme and developing a sense of ownership that will help mitigate potential sources of conflict"]

column5: ["Urban resilience is a new and upcoming theme for a number of Oxfam country programmes, regions and affiliates. However, as a Confederation, Oxfam currently lacks a common understanding of urban resilience, and our Theories of Change (TOCs), tools, and approaches remain largely relevant for rural contexts given that it is where the bulk of our existing footprint is. How do we apply Oxfam's resilience definition in urban contexts? How does it look like in urban settings? A number of Oxfam country offices and partners want to engage in a participatory and empowering processes to harvest, co -create, exchange, and use knowledge and embed an appetite for collective learning. This process of generating and sharing knowledge drawn from different experiences and contexts is the basis for cross -regional knowledge exchange. It will engage more staff and partners from other locations who will be invited to join during the process. The rapid urbanization rates and incidence of disasters in many of the regions and countries that we work in is making it imperative for Oxfam to adapt, design and learn about approaches and tools that enable us to be more effective in dealing with urban resilience challenges.  Learning on past and present experiences will help us increase quality of programmes and inspire new countries and teams. Kenya program will strengthen understanding of the drivers of inequality and invest in brokering partnerships, convene wider coalitions and strengthen capacity of civil society organisations. The aim is to strengthen accountability and measure dis aggregated changes made in the lives of women and from those in society in general. This list illustrates the range of underlying ToCs informing Oxfam's approach to urban resilience."]

column2: ['Time To Care: Improving Gender Equality and Care Infrastructure in Kenya']
column5: ["Oxfam in collaboration with partners will implement a 6 -year Programme dubbed ‘Time to Care' in Nairobi, Mombasa, Kiambu and Nakuru counties in Kenya. The project aims to improve gender equality and care infrastructure for women and girls in Kenya.  The Care Project will directly benefit 5,916 people and 2,021,800 people indirectly and will take an intersectional approach challenging gender social norms and inequalities experienced by domestic workers and unpaid caregivers, particularly women and girls in Kenya. The project aims to ensure that they are treated with dignity and respect within their communities and are able to fully exercise agency and decision -making so that they can lead fulfilling lives and have equal opportunities to participate fully in economic, social, cultural, and political spaces. Some of the innovative approaches will include a combination of research, stakeholder engagement i.e., employment -based influencers (opinion leaders, traditional and religious leaders, media, teachers, female employers of domestic workers etc.) behaviour change communication campaigns and capacity building."]

column2: ['Support for better taxation in the extractives sector in Zambia']
column5: ["The project sets out to do the following:  • Contribute to the formulation of an Extractive Industries Transparency Initiatives (EITI) policy in Zambia which embraces key provisions and principles for mineral revenue sharing transparency and accountability, consistent with global payment disclosure norms. To this end, the project team will advocate for policy and legislation from the Ministry of Mines and the legislature. Oxfam Zambia will also support civil society analysis of EITI reconciliation reports and company payment disclosures and help capacitate Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) and media groups to better use this information in advocacy efforts. The project team will also advocate for the inclusion of beneficial ownership requirements in national legislation. The project will also undertake activities to follow -up from past research studies conducted regarding taxation, transfer mispricing and bilateral investment treaties and will also include targeted corporate campaigning based on the results of these studies.   • Engage the Ministry of Mines and various relevant Parliamentary committees to encourage the adoption of the proposed revenue sharing mechanism guidelines. Alongside these efforts, the project team will also help progress the Kulinganiza (EiU) campaign with partner organizations through a focus on mineral revenue sharing mechanism as a tool to decrease inequality. Oxfam Zambia will also undertake training of local government officials on the topic of mineral revenue sharing as well as train local Natural Resource Watch Groups and Ward Development Committees on revenue tracking. The project team will also promote dialogue on the topic of mineral revenue sharing by holding side events and panel discussions at the Alternative Mining Indaba and other platforms.    • Utilize the Civil Society Poverty Observatory Group  - CS POG (a network through which Oxfam's resource Governance programme is delivered) as the overall banner carrying the bigger me"]

column2: ['Increasing commuinity benefits from extractives']

column2: ['WASH and Protection Response to the Syrian Refugee Crisis in North Bekaa']
column5: ["Oxfam will continue to provide access to gender -sensitive latrines , adhering to a maximum of 15 persons/latrine. For every latrine, Oxfam provides a one -off cleaning kit. All construction works abide by Oxfam's Safe Programming principles, ensuring access is cleared of obstruction and that there are door handles, locks, lighting (solar) and rope handles for support. Location, design and positioning are selected in consultation with refugees, with a focus on women and girls, and persons with disabilities (PwD). • For facility (latrines and water tanks) rehabilitation, Oxfam shifted maintenance from implementation via contractors to a community -led modality. Oxfam selects Community Technical Volunteers (CTVs) and provides them with (on -the -job) training, a WASH facility toolkit  and spare parts. CTVs, supported by Oxfam engineers, monitor and document the needs of facilities. These are compiled into a Bill of Quantities (BoQ) and Oxfam reviews and authorizes the works. CTVs obtain the material from an Oxfam -contracted hardware store at an average of CAD 39.42/facility. This market -based approach greatly reduces maintenance costs compared with private contractors that charge CAD 105.12/facility, empowers beneficiaries to engage with local markets, and prevents overcharging of refugees. Once works are completed, Oxfam checks their quality before handing them over to the HHs.  • Ongoing desludging services will be maintained for existing and new latrines and septic tanks via Oxfam -contracted desludgers to ensure functionality, mitigate community tensions within the ISs that arise from sharing latrines, reduce open defecation, and prevent proliferation of hand -dug pits that expose people to health and protection risks. Desludging is conducted every 2 months, as per latrine pit design requirements. column2: ['Finding approach to reduce violence against women in Deep South']

column2: ['Liberia Empowerment Programme on Women Rights (Haki Mkononi)']
column5: ["The project will focus on community -level empowerment. It is evident that the greatest impact of bad policies, poor implementation of good policies, and the lack of good leadership is felt at the community level. This is continuing because the majority of the people who are within the lower and lowest echelons of the decision making pyramid are not consulted in policy development, nor are they fully educated on their role in effecting policy and reaping the resulting benefits. Based on this, the action will take a bottom -up approach, which will include the empowerment of community -based women's rights organisations and moving up to engaging national state actors for policy influencing. These approaches will focus on articulating:   • Article 6 and 7: Equality in marriage and divorce, 18 years as the minimum age of marriage, preference for monogamy, and protection of wives' rights in polygamous relationships;  • Article 14: Right to control fertility; protection from HIV/AIDS; and obligation to provide adequate, affordable, and available health services and medical abortion under certain conditions; and  • Article 15, 18 & 21: Women's land rights and the right to equitable inheritance to matrimonial and parental property areas which will lead to informed policy influencing and enhance women rights.  Once the capacity of people at the community level is built and strengthened, self -actualization ensues and the confidence to constructively engage government and demand them to account and ensure protection is advanced.   • Article 5:  Elimination of harmful cultural practices, prohibition of FGM (Female Genital Mutilation) backed by sanctions, obligation to provide public awareness programs."]
